root.publications: Lissarrague, Amanda & Jim Wafer. 2008. Handbook of Aboriginal Languages of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. Nambucca Heads, NSW: Muurrbay Aboriginal Language and Culture Co-operative Ltd.ISBN 9780977535187
root.tree-val: Yarli, subtree of Pama-Nyungan: Lissarrague and Wafer 2008
root.pub-comments: "The first grouping that we list here is what has become widely known in the literature as the 'Yarli Subgroup' from 'yarli,' the word for 'person' in Malyangapa" (Lissarrague and Wafer 2008: 289).

child.publications: Lissarrague, Amanda & Jim Wafer. 2008. Handbook of Aboriginal Languages of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. Nambucca Heads, NSW: Muurrbay Aboriginal Language and Culture Co-operative Ltd.ISBN 9780977535187

child.alt-names: Jadliaura, Yardliyawara, Aluri, Alury, Arabatura, Arkaba-tura, Arkabatura, Eura, Jadliaura, Jadlijawara, Jadloori, Wonoka, Yadliaura, Yadlikowera, Yadliyawarra, Yadlouri, Yaldikowera

child.publications: Lissarrague, Amanda & Jim Wafer. 2008. Handbook of Aboriginal Languages of New South Wales and the Australian Capital Territory. Nambucca Heads, NSW: Muurrbay Aboriginal Language and Culture Co-operative Ltd.ISBN 9780977535187
child.tree-val: Yarli, subtree of Pama-Nyungan: Lissarrague and Wafer 2008
child.pub-comments: "We suggest that the location of Ngurunta, and the opinion of Hercus and Austin's informants, indicate a more likely connection with the Yarli languages, in particular Yardliyawarra. So we include a reference to Ngurunta here as a (hypothetical) dialect of Yardliyawarra. But since there is no linguistic information available, there is not much that can be said about it with any certainty" (Lissarrague and Wafer 2008: 290).
